titleStmt.title: The golden pippin: an English burletta, in three acts. As it is performed at the Theatre-Royal, Covent-Garden. By the author of Midas.
titleStmt.author: O'Hara, Kane, 1714?-1782.

fileDesc.extent: 54 600dpi bitonal TIFF page images and SGML/XML encoded text

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: The golden pippin: an English burletta, in three acts. As it is performed at the Theatre-Royal, Covent-Garden. By the author of Midas.
titleStmt.author: O'Hara, Kane, 1714?-1782.

notesStmt.note: The author of Midas = Kane O'Hara.
At foot of titlepage: Price one shilling and sixpence.
A variant has no price at the foot of the titlepage.
Reproduction of original from the British Library.

Electronic data. Farmington Hills, Mich. : Thomson Gale, 2003. Page image (PNG). Digitized image of the microfilm version produced in Woodbridge, CT by Research Publications, 1982-2002 (later known as Primary Source Microfilm, an imprint of the Gale Group).

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE GOLDEN PIPPIN: AN ENGLISH BURLETTA, IN THREE ACTS.
As it is performed at the THEATRE-ROYAL, COVENT-GARDEN.
LONDON: Printed for T. BECKET, in the Strand.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: IT is but Juſtice to the abſent Author to declare, in contradiction to many idle Reports, and injurious Paragraphs that in this Piece, as in his former, he only propoſed an innocent Burleſque; never thinking Ribaldry, Profaneneſs, or Perſonal Satire, a proper Entertainment for the Public, to whoſe experienced Candour and Indulgence he ſubmits the following BURLETTA.

div.head: ACT I. SCENE I.
div.p: The Curtain riſing, diſcovers a Splendid Pavilion in the Clouds; JUNO, PALLAS, and VENUS at a Card-Table playing at Tredrille, on one Side a Table, with Goblets, &c. IRIS, in Waiting, During a Symphony, VENUS ſhuffles and deals. PALLAS frets at her bad Cards.
div.stage: AIR. TRIO. Franoeſco. PALLAS, JUNO, VENUS.

l.hi: I Paſs—I've done ſo all the night.
You ſcarcely Paſs one hand in ten.
The Cards owe me a ſpite.
This Lady knows you;—ſo do I.
You dealt the Cards—and we could ſpy.
But loſers muſt have leave to pout.
But loſers muſt ha' leave to pout.

div.stage: (Juno and Pallas riſe in heat, and come forward. Venus ſits ſtill, counting and pocketing her gains.)

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Hang cards!

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: As I'm a ſinner!
I haven't—ſince laſt Chriſtmas—ris'n a winner.

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: That's hard!—So bad a run may well chagrin one:
Venus is quite a dab.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Dab!—She's—a keen one; At all games—plays th' whole game.

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: Aye, aye!

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Match none has; For ſleight of hand,—will ſlip an ace—with Jonas.

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: Gambles deep too!

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Well may—who never loſes: At Putt, poor girls!—ſh' as beggar'd the Nine Muſes;
Fine as a Queen o' ginger-bread—parades it;
But ne'er has paid the wages of her Maids yet.

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: Like enough—for the Graces,—and 'tis ſcandalous,
Go mother-naked.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Skin-flint!—ſo to randle us! 'Twould vex a ſaint.—

l.hi: Has pick'd up, here, of chouſing us;

lg.l: By Pam! I'll pluck a crow wi' you.

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: Nay,—Pallas!

div.stage: [Venus advances to them, ſmiling jocoſely at Pallas.]

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: Miſs,—you're—funny, Poor dear!—has't loſt it' temper with it' money? ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Pert chitty face! 'cauſe leud fops call you—pretty;
You fancy thoſe—patch-clenches—ſmart—and witty.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: Pretty!—the fools!—do they, indeed?—Ah, tell us.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Conceited moppet!

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: Sure, Miſs,—you a'n't jealous.

div.stage: [Takes out a pocket-glaſs, and views herſelf affectedly.]

l.hi: Can I help it?—No, not I;—
Some good luck too—'tis my duty
If the Smarts of the Sky
No, no—If I do, may I die.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Don't rouze me, Bold-face!—if your tongue's ſo flippant, I'll take y' a chuck—as ſhall chop off the tip on't.

div.stage: [Pallas advances upon her; ſhe takes ſhelter behind Juno.]

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: I'll ſwear the peace:—keep at arms-length, Virago!
She'll brain me, Mâm!

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: —Well, had I don't long a-go.

sp.speaker: Ven
sp.p: Your tongue's no ſlander—for that, not a button
Care I;—but I can't ſtand your fiſt o' mutton.

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: Nuts to me, This—I hope, 'twill be a ſcuffle;
My ſtars! what was't cou'd thus your tempers ruffle?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Her gibes,

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: Her rants.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Don't ſnouch then!

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: Don't you hector!

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: Faults on both ſides—ſit down—come, I'll direct here.
And Iris!—ſtir, wench!—fill about the nectar.

sp.speaker: Pal. Venus—
sp.p: your quips would Patient Griſel canker,
Howe'er, ſhake hands!

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: Here, Miſs, I bear no rancour.

div.stage: AIR IV. Touch the Thing, you Baſtard.
(All ſit, and Iris ſerves them with Nectar.

l.hi: Or ſhew me that glib ſpeaker,
With her mouth full of liquor.

div.stage: SCENE changes to a Wild Heath.
Enter Momus, in the habit of the Antique Court Jeſter. Walks to and fro impatiently.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: By Jingo! if Erynnis—from the Heſperides,
Steals me the Dragon's Apple-we'll ha'merry days. Augh!—ho!—oa!—
Court's grown damn'd hum-drum:—Jove, poor Noodle!
Does nought but muddle.—
Juno too—turn'd ſo—mim, forſooth, Butter will ſcarce melt in her mouth.
But th' Apple—yes—I'll throw—that ſquib among 'em—
Shall ſtir the humours—as a waſp had ſtung 'em,

div.stage: AIR V. Behind the Buſh in the Garden,

l.hi: The turn of a ſtraw or a pin does;
And fling Heaven out o' the windows.

lg.l: Jove of my puppets but is chief;

l.hi: I doat on a ſnug bit o' miſchief.

div.stage: [To him enter running, as from purſuit, Erynnis, holding the Golden Apple in her hand, and habited as an old witch.]

sp.speaker: Ery.
sp.p: Here, Momus, 'tis—at laſt;—I'm all o'er dripping.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Good Hag!—Now quick, to Juno's palace tripping,
Amongſt the three Sultanas drop this Pippin.

sp.speaker: Ery.
sp.p: That Dragon! Oh! we've had a-do moſt helliſh,
Burn him!—for Pippins he has ſpoil'd my reliſh.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: No fear;—I'll fool him with ſome rigma-rol,—
Pat on his back, and ſcratch his pol.—

sp.speaker: Ery.
sp.p: But I—(in terror)

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: You—muſt plump down to Hell,—to Pluto;
I've writ a card to him.—

sp.speaker: Ery.
sp.p: Any where,—in tuto.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Off! off!

div.stage: [She takes to her heels, Momus ſkulks aſide.—Enter impetuouſly the Dragon, ſearching on every ſide, during the ſymphony, to find her—then]—.

l.hi: Stop thief! Stop thief! Stop thief!

div.stage: Momus comes forth, and accoſts him familiarly.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Ha,—my old friend!—how is't?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Saw you that Beldam Erynnis ſcamper by?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Faith, Sir,—ſhe—ſeldom Viſits theſe parts:—yet paſs'd—within this half-hour,
Hobbling—to Juno,—with ſome fruit—you—gave her.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: She lies,—ſhe ſtole it;—Gave! give her a halter!
Her due,—The thief!—

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Stole! ay, an old defaulter.—
Sue out a warrant—

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Sue!—the Queen has got it,—I may go whiſtle—Piqued,—Repiqued,—Capotted!—

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Pluck up,—talk big to her,—
(Aſide) I'll egg on this hot-head.

l.hi: Why then roar, and whiſk your tail.
But I may be ſent to Jail.
On my word, be won't demur.
And be ſure you put it home t' her:
I ſhall pelt on, 'till I came t' her,
I ſhall pelt, &c. Thank you, Sir.

div.stage: A knocking; then Juno's bell rings vehemently. Enter Iris running. Juno, Pallas, and Venus, enter on the other ſide.

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: High time, Miſs Lazyboots! where ha' you been lolloping?

sp.speaker: Iris.
sp.p: Sure, Mem—at the firſt tinkle—I came galloping.

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: Who rapp'd?

sp.speaker: Iris.
sp.p: Beau Cupid, Mêm, aſk'd for Miſs Pallas.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: For me? the Whelp!—I'd ſee him to the Gallows.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: Gallows! Mâm.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Ay—'twill be his prank concluſive, As he goes on.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: Mâm—ſhe's downright abuſive.

l.hi: But ah! Sweet Miſs, your temper keep!
Your Peace my Boy ſhall ne'er invade;
Cupid ſhall not break your ſleep,
You ſhall ſtill remain a Maid.
Roſes alone ne'er deck that thorn.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: I'd mince the blinkard—to a ſalmagondi.

div.stage: [Enter Iris in a fright to Juno, THE APPLE in her hand.]

sp.speaker: Iris.
sp.p: Oh! Mêm!

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: Are you bewitch'd, Girl?—What has ſtunn'd ye?
Haſt ſeen a Ghoſt—

sp.speaker: Iris.
sp.p: Worſe, Mêm—that hag—Erynnis.

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: Got in, d'ye ſay?—I wou'dn't for five guineas—

sp.speaker: Iris.
sp.p: In troth, I think, that Witch the Devil-in-is.

div.stage: AIR IX. Sweet, if you love me, &c.

l.hi: Told by the Porter and the Page,
You'd ha' thought ſhe'd burſt with rage.
Skips, I muſt ſee the Queen, and will—
Dear Ma'm, ſays I—the Queen is ill,

lg.l: Takes James's Powder, and Ward's Pill.

l.hi: Eccho'd they to all her aſkings.
To this Pippin bid her ſmell,
I'll engage ſhe'll ſoon be well.
I box'd the Fox this morn, ſays ſhe,

lg.l: And from th' Heſperian Dragon's Tree

l.hi: Hoik'd off with 't to her Majeſty:

div.stage: Juno and Pallas alternately admire the Apple, Venus deſiring to look at it.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: With your leave, Mâm—

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: Suppoſe that three ſhares equal We make—

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Oh—that—Erynnis might—not take well.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: Bleſs us!—'t has grown—with an Inſcription on it.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Have the ſnails trac'd a tag of ſome—French ſonnet?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: Nah, Miſs; plain Engliſh—and to Me directed.
(inſulting) A wind-fall, Ladies!—yet—one can't reject it.
So, poz—I will not have—my goods triſected.

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: Yours!

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Yours!

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: Mine.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: By what right?

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: What title?—Fool-y'!

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: What—when ye hear—will make you both look bluely.

div.stage: Reads to them diſtinctly the Inſcription, without RECITATIVE.
div.q: TO THE FAIREST IN HEAV'N, BE THIS APPLE GIV'N.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Stand clear, Mâm—let me to her—(to Venus) Shut your fly-trap, Your title I'll ſoon quaſh elſe—with a tight rap,

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: I bar blows—yet that Fruit I'll have,—depend on't;
'Tis mine, (to Venus) ſo, give it me—and there's an end on't.

l.hi: Yield; or beware, left rage, diſdain,
The claim my rank, my charms ſuſtain,

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Nay, Madam!—Sure—my claim's the more undoubted;
So (to Venus) give it me—and ſay no more about it.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: Ladies, for Pow'r, Arms, Arts, I don't diſpute ye,
But—all the world (bridling) gives me the crack for Beauty.

l.hi: Such rank conceit! It mads me.

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: You Trapes!

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: You Demi-rep! you hatter'd Dowdy, Nam'd of a day with us—you're—

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: Oh! No-body.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: Two to one's odds;—but Ladies,—ſince you crow ſo,
Let Jove judge.

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: Done!

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Done!

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: He's a Virtuoſo
In female matters.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Is he?

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: Troth—but ſo, ſo.

div.stage: [Here they are alarm'd by a tumultuous roaring without. A Symphony of Terror and Confuſion; at the cloſe burſts in the Heſperian Dragon. Juno and Venus run into a corner affrighted; Pallas undaunted.]

l.hi: I'll have it Cruſt and Crumb,
If up with her I come,

div.stage: [Crawls about roaring, Juno and Venus angry, yet terrified.]

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: Hark y' me, Dragon! you're a ſaucy fellor!
I'll have ye kick'd down ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Vap'ring Ale-ſwiller!

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: Tip him Meduſa's Muz!

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Hand here my Aegis!

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Boh!—I'll indict you all—in Banco Regis.

div.stage: [He roars, they ſcream, Pallas ſtamps; a rapid Symphony.]

l.hi: Keep the King's Peace within theſe walls, ho!
Ladies! you can't think it civil,
In Heaven to play the Devil!
You, to keep this holly-rag on!

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: An' if you go to that—you pert Intruder! By whoſe authority are you thus rude here?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Don Jove, our thunder-thumping Caliph, From doze at Council-Board, Upſtarting with a bounce, Rapp'd out,—Coxnouns! Call me my Bailiff! Scud, Hermes!—fetch me word, Is Billingſgate transferr'd To Juno's Malepardus?—By the Lord, Her Goſſips Throats had need be of Bull-leather.
Tell 'em—I'll come—and tole their Jolls together.

l.hi: I proteſt,—'tis this Beaſt—will not reſt.
We've no reſt,—not the leaſt,—for this Beaſt.
I'd root th' whole garden—for one fardin.
Yes, I'll firk you, and jerk you, and yerk you.
I'll make you fly—I'll know why.
By cock and pie—you vamp or I.
Hence to your fly—or, Filth! you die.
Jove, by and by,—your ſuit will try.
A lie—a lie,—juſt cut and dry.

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: SCENE, a Chamber in the Celeſtial Palace.
[Momus meets the Dragon in Chains, led to Priſon by one of the Furies.]

sp.speaker: MOMUS.
sp.p: AH, ah!—in Crib, Sir Drag.?

sp.speaker: Drag.
sp.p: Now, bail me, Momus!

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: I'd ſee you hang'd firſt.

sp.speaker: Drag.
sp.p: Get along,—and be Curſt!—Why did I truſt a Courtier's Promiſe?

div.stage: AIR I. A Stage Dance Tune.
The Fury laſhes him on. Exeunt.
SCENE changes to Jupiter's Hall of Audience.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—ha! ha! ha!
Three Cats—I left 'em at it,—ſpitting, —ſcratching,
(Seeing Jupiter) Gadſo!
Now, What can that wiſe Nob be hatching?

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: How ſhall I get this tangled hank unravell'd?
Put to my trumps, and gravell'd!
'Twou'd dumb found, Wizard, Merlin, or Friar Bacon;
Aye, all the Square-caps from Oxford to Pekin.
No making head or tail on't—which way ſoe'er I turn it—
If I know how to act—I'm a ſous'd gurnet.
Ha! that Firebrand Erynnis! (Cou'd I but trap her, With what good will I'd ſtrap her!)
I'll be hang'd, but 'twas ſhe that kick'd this duſt up,
None but ſhe—miſchief-maker! (The Devil take her!)
Amongſt my proud leaſh of Ninnies.
But—I—for her provide will; Yes—I'll have her fairly truſs'd up, Tho' the old Trot ſhou'd mount for't, Who can call me to account for't?
Or, if not ſtrung—ſhe ſhall—mill-doll—in Bridewell.

l.hi: To bilk him will be braver.

div.stage: [Towards the cloſe of the Air, Momus advances to him.]

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: That's fix'd then.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: Yes, yes—I've wound up my bottom.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Roundly; like a true Solomon— (aſide) of Gotham.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: But how to ſtill their clamours—there's the matter.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Depute ſome Mortal for their Arbitrator; 'Twill pull 'em down a peg.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: 'Twill, 'twill—the ſluts!
I'll do't—to fiddle-ſtrings 'twill fret their guts.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Oh! they'll cajole you with their Ifs and Buts.
Didn't they coax you in your beer to impris'n The Dragon but for claiming what was his'n?

l.hi: Doxies wind you as they pleaſe;
Thro' their eyes you then diſcover,
That the Moon's a huge Green-cheeſe,

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: I was a green-horn then—no penetration—
But now I'm come to years—

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Not—of diſcretion.—

div.stage: Mercury enters haſtily, and twitches Jupiter's ſleeve.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Moſt Doughty—pleaſe edge this way.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: Eh! what mutter y'?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: The Goddeſſes—at loggerheads—i' th' Buttery.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: Fight dog, fight bear—I?—Blood I I've other bus'neſs:
Muſt Jove fit Judge—on Dimples—Snouts—and Pigſnies?
Bid 'em ſcrub up as clean as hands can make 'em.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Shou'd they run ruſt—

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: By Jericho!—I'd flake 'em.—
(to Mercury) Conduct them, you, to Ida—There young Paris
Shall view, and there give Judgment, which moſt fair is.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: What?—Paris of Troy, That Hobble-de-Hoy, He Lord Chief Juſtice conſtituted! If h'as guts in his brains, or in's ſkull eyes. Sure, ſure, this Heav'n-embroiling Prize Cannot be long diſputed.

sp.speaker: Fiſher. Pallas and Juno,

l.hi: Never, no never can bear the bell.

sp.l: For Venus herſelf is a Nonpareil.

div.stage: Jupiter and Momus come forward, as continuing their converſation.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: What comes o'you?

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: Oh! I—after the Inſpection—
May call—to hear—which carry'd the Election.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Mum!—yonder's Juno— (going)

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: Aye,—my Meſſage—ſnubs.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Now—keep it up—be ſure—a few dry rubs
Will give her Majeſty—the Mulligrubs.

l.hi: Since 'tis writ in the volume of Fate,
Females muſt lay their account ſoon or late;
She muſt ſubmit has a God to her Mate.
Maſter you'll be—and your Wife be a ſlave.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: How now, Dame Partlet?—
sp.stage: Enter Juno, ſtalking haughtily up to him; her arms a-kimbo.)
sp.p: (aſide) Now—ſhe opes her Budget.

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: So, Sir! Our cauſe—you ſcorn, it ſeems,—to judge it.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: I waſh my hands o't:—woundy tickliſh Matters
Theſe!—How decree—'twixt my own Wife and Daughters?

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: Then, Sir, who ſhall?

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: Why,—Paris,—Son of Priam,—
Genimede's Coz—a better Judge than I am.

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: Finely fobb'd off! Had it been Madam Semele—

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: Juno,—go, ſcold your Maids;—do—mind your Family.

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: No, with all Heav'n for my due I'd grapple.
Were there an Orchard; mine were every Apple.

l.hi: With your Wife, Sir, ne'er diſpute,
Due to her the choiceſt fruit,
Due to her the branch and tree;
And you know ſhe'll have her right;
Yes, Sir, Morning Noon, and Night.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: Right!—Stuff!—between us, None has a legal right to it, but Venus.

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: Fool that I was, my Huſband to refer to!

sp.speaker: Venus!
sp.p: —a ſneaking kindneſs—Goat!—for Her too?—

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: My Daughter?

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: Wert your Mother?

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: Why my Pet Lamb Ought not go looſe—It ſhould be lodg'd in Bedlam.
Theſe Maggots, Child—

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: By each new Trull ſupplanted!

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: I'll be divorc'd—

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: The very Thing I wanted.

l.hi: Let not your Fury gull y';
The Chum you pawn'd your Nuptial
You broke all vows—you hot Bell-ſwagger!
Act the Swan, act the Bull,
At the Gooſe, at the Calf.
For a taſte of the ſwitch.
Your Wife a caſt-off ſta • e.
Wife Wife thoſe taunts are ſta • e.
Yet you can't ſay black's her nail.
Yet you urge them tooth and nail
I'll not ſit down mum chance.
I'll rove, and take my chance.
You ſhall ſee the Devil dance.
Tho' I ſee the Devil dance.
More Sacks on the Mill!—No, no,

sp.speaker: Jup.

l.hi: Jack muſt have his Jill—I trow;

sp.l: And, as Jove, I will—ha' fix.

div.head: ACT III.
div.stage: SCENE, a Chamber in the Celeſtial Palace.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: I Met 'em—Frieſland hens! their feathers bruſtling
All the wrong way.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: That's what they get by buſtling On the High-horſe with Me—

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Poor Venus ſaid nought.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: True——But—for my Jezebel, and yond' Miſs Dreadnought—

l.hi: I'll taw them ſoft as old glove,
The Drabs ſhall know I'm Czar above;
To maunder at the will of Jove.
Mine are the reins—and to the bit,
Tag, Rag, and Bob-tail, ſhall ſubmit.

div.stage: SCENE, MOUNT IDA. Paris is diſcovered admiring his own Finery.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: C'eſt quelque choſe cela—no more a Ruſtick ſcrubbiſh,
Paris at Court has duſted off his Rubbiſh.

l.hi: But now let me flaunt it,
Rant flirt it, and jaunt it,
Gallant it, and dreſs it away;
I warrant I carry the day.
Loſe thouſands, and call it mere Sport;

lg.l: Sweet Paris, the Pink of the Court!

div.stage: Paris turns, and ſpies Mercury advancing. What chap comes here? trick'd out ſo nicely!
Enter to him Mercury. (He ſtands bowing at a distance.) Dem' mauvaiſe honte—So thus—conciſely.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: By garb, gait, and aſpect, you're Francois.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: But whence—and whither now?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: My Errand At preſent is—

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: To me—I warrant.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: E'en ſo.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: With my poor perſon ſmitten?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: No, Sir—a matter—You'd ſcarce hit on.
This Apple—(produces the Golden Apple)

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Aye.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: (Tho' no nice Fruit 'tis) Has ſet by the ears three tip-top Beauties.
Th' Inſcription—there's the bone—

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: To THE FAIREST!

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: 'Till that point's ſettled—Heav'n can ne'er reſt.—

sp.speaker: Juno,
sp.p: Miſs Pallas Venus—ſtiffly
Lay claim to't—

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Well—mon cher!

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Why, briefly—
You're nam'd their Judge—

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: A precious bawble To ſet three Goddeſſes—at ſquabble!

l.hi: A Goddeſs, like an earthly Dame,
And turn from deareſt Friend to Foe.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: But why to me this Beauty-reference?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: You, Sir, Jove knows,—can gueſs the difference—
Betwixt—a Nymph—and a Nut-cracker—

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Not half ſo well as he,—th'old Smacker!

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Him they'd think partial,—intereſted, Therefore in you his Pow'r is veſted.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What Jeopardy?—My Caſe quite deſperate?—
Can pleaſe but one,—two muſt exaſperate!—

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Do as you like—but—leave off prating.
You keep their Goddeſsſhips a-waiting.

lg.l: I hope, Sir, you'll protect me.

div.stage: Re-enter Mercury, leading Juno, whom be announces moſt ceremoniouſly. She advances with over-ſtrained haughtineſs.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Queen Juno, Sir, (bows) Jove's Conſort—

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: Leſs Palaver.
We've other fiſh to fry—(beckons Mercury away; be ſneaks off.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Ma'am,—by your Favour—

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: Meat for your Lord!—I thought you better knew me.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: La fiere!—a three-pil'd Prude, conſume me!

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: Lad, don't you feel yourſelf, at times, ambitious Of Pow'r—and Wealth?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Ma foi! they're both delicious.

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: Both you may have—

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: For me paſs Sentence, And you will bleſs your Stars for our Acquaintance.

lg.l: Then ſhall the Chiefs from Europe

l.hi: Crouching each to hold thy Stirrup,
Proud to ſerve thee like Seapoys.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Why—faith—She offers-like a Bidder.
Nabob!—Bon ça!—let me—conſider: Bengal—a damn'd—long—voyage thither.
(aſide) Now un grand Coup—You're warm—and I in Spirits—
(to her) 'Gad, Ma'am, let's uſe your Huſband as he merits.

sp.speaker: Down Derry Derry.

l.hi: Sweet Revenge there is a Clue to,

sp.l: Wou'd you take a Fool's advice,—

l.hi: We may dub him in a trice.

sp.l: Dans le Bon ton—Down derry derry.

div.stage: (Juno in furious indignation turns fiercely upon him.)

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: Indeed!—'Squire Hotſpur!—two words to that Bargain.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: N'importe—There needs no farther arguing.

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: To be ſent haggling here with ſuch a Puppy!
Well, Jove, remember this, if I ben't up wi' ye.

l.hi: I'll ſhake your curtains every night,
And you ſhall tremble with affright;
I'll bounce, I'll flounce, I'll rant and rave,
And you ſhall be a very ſlave.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—
Dans le Bon ton,—hey, derry derry.
Dins le Bon ton,
Sur le Gazon,

div.stage: (until Mercury re-enters, introducing Pallas. He bows and retires. She ſtands ſullen; Paris hops partly up to kiſs her.)

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Servant, my dear,!—

div.stage: (She repulſes him with a violent puſh.)

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Since when? Spruce Maſter Jemmy!

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.stage: (aſide, his hands on his breaſt as in pain)
sp.p: That Peg ſhe had from Broughton—demme!
Well, Joan of Arc!—my frumpiſh Miſſy
You might, as well ha' let me kiſs ye.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Paris, no Airs—That Pippin, without muſing,
Adjudge to me—

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Bon;—for your Skill in bruiſing.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: I'll make your Fortune:—Call me elſe, Canary.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: My Fortune, Miſs!—

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Ay, in the Milita—ry.

sp.speaker: Bates.

l.hi: Shall gain thee store of plunder!
Ne'er ſaw ſuch piles of Mammon!

sp.l: Raiſe, young Paris, raiſe thy name!

l.hi: Away, away to Wealth and Fame!

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Zauns, Miſs—What ſee you in my Figure, As if I lov'd to draw a Trigger?

l.hi: Let Heroes delight in the toils of the war,
In maims, blood, and bruiſes and blows;
Not a ſword, but a ſword-knot rejoices the Fair:
And what art rough Soldiers to Beaux?
Away then with laurels! come Beauty and Love,
And ſilence the trumpet and drum;
Let me with ſoft Myrtle my brows bear inwove,

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Daſtard!—Be henceforth, (ſince you're for that duty)
No Officer of mine.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Ni vous—my Beauty.
Now, Merc'ry!—let the Cyprian Belle come.
sp.stage: Enter Mercury, hands out Pallas, and introduces Venus; then bows, and exit. She advances, ſmirking Paris, tho' ſtruck with her beauty, trips to ſalute her with his uſual pertneſs.
sp.p: Ay this! (to her) Permettez-moi! (kiſſes her)

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: And welcome.
sp.stage: (leering, and chucking him under the chin)
sp.p: My Paris! can you love?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: No fooliſh item.
Yes, Ma'am—kind ſouls!—I never ſlight'em.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: Well, there's a Judge—one Menelaus—in Sparta;
(A Judge's creſt is—Horns—by Magna Charta)
That Judge, he hath a wife—that Wife hight Nelly,
But ſuch a Nell!—at ev'ry glance
The cockles of your heart would dance,
Warm'd as if by Vermicelli.

l.hi: Thou of heroes ſhalt lead the van!
Faint heart ne'er fair lady won.
Be bold, and play the Man!
Oh, ſuch bliſs you've no idea;

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Agreed—touchez!—Now for a Barrel Of Golden Pippins—We ſhall never quarrel.
I'll call the Ladies in that went hence.
sp.stage: (Takes the Apple in his hand, croſſes the Stage, and calls aloud)
sp.p: Mercury!—I'm going to Paſs Sentence.

div.stage: (Enter on one Side Mercury, uſhering in Juno and Pallas; on the other, Venus alone.)

l.hi: Reſts here Placing it as a Bouquet in Venus's Boſom.—tho' Loſers mutiny.

sp.l: Fair ye to the bone are;—

div.stage: (Juno and Pallas walk to and fro, ſtomachful; Venus and Paris bowing and curtſying. Mercury ſtands tittering.

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: Buzzard!—in real Beauty, Ignoramus!

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: That lewd Trull's Perſon was his Fee to bam us.

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.p: For this,—an old houſe o'er! your Sconce I'll tumble.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Poltroon!—Since War you dread, its Din ſhall rumble
In both your Ears—

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Ladies!—You're not to grumble.—

div.stage: AIR XII. QUARTETTO. Fye now, prithee, John.

l.hi: You no title bad—no, nor you.

sp.speaker: Pal.

l.hi: And he's a rogue—has cheated us!

sp.l: But Pallas won't be treated thus:

l.hi: A Pippin, is not worth this fuſs!
Do, you fool? obſerve my face,
My ſhape and air, and every grace:
The brighteſt Queen that e'er was ſeen!

div.stage: (A furious Symphony; then enter haſtily Jupiter, rageouſly angry, the thunder-bolt in his hand.)

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: Ye ſpiteful Jades!—threat not my Puny Judge, elſe
For him I will, myſelf, take up the Cudgels—The proudeſt She that with him dares to meddle, I'll make dance Barnaby—without a Fiddle!

sp.speaker: Galluppi.
sp.l: He judg'd it juſt as I did.—

l.hi: Ye cou'd not all Three have it;

sp.l: He to the FAIREST gave it.

l.hi: That he had Eyes to ſee,
And that the Truth he ſpoke?
If ſtill ye're ſtiff and ſturdy,

sp.l: Look to't—I'm at a word wi' ye;—

l.hi: And now my mind ye know.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: The Dragon!—Dear Papa! have ſome regard on him.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: Well mov'd! (nodding to Mercury) Go, ſet the Dragon free—I pardon him.

div.stage: (Exit Mercury. Enter Dragon; making profound obeiſance to all.)
JUPITER, JUNO, PALLAS, VENUS, PARIS, DRAGON.

l.hi: I ne'er ſhou'd ha' grudg'd it.
Why to me this mortal hatred?
Why to me this ſpleen inveterate?
Why to her this mortal hatred?
Why to her ſuch ſpleen inveterate?
Beauty's my ſole Gift of Nature;
Thank her, ſhe cou'd give no greater.
I have no patience with ſuch flirts.
Ne'er heed. We'll ſtick in both their ſkirts.
Blood! don't again my paſſion rouze.
He's your Papa, Miſs, and your Spouſe.
If you will not be cool,
I have for Scolds a School,
You ſee Sir, we are cool.
We ſhall not need that School.
They will not need that School.
You ſee, Sir, they are cool.

sp.speaker: Jup., Juno., Pal., Ven., Par., Dra.

l.hi: This day ſhall be High Jubilee

sp.speaker: Jup., Juno., Pal., Ven., Par., Dra.

l.hi: Let this day be High Jubilee

sp.speaker: Jup., Juno., Pal., Ven., Par., Dra.

div.head: ERRATUM.
div.p: P. 8. for "Scene changes to a Wild Heath"—read "Scens changes to a Wood."
